values.alignmentText: Russia offers vast taiga and lakes for family trips. City air can be hazy near industry, but nature escapes are easy outside hubs.
Russia faces noticeable warming - hotter summers and permafrost thaw; risks are manageable with planning and strong community resilience.
Russia brings long, cold winters and mild summers; winter gear is essential, but summers are generally comfortable.
Russia's major cities regularly show PM2.5 spikes in winter from coal heating and traffic; coastal towns typically have cleaner air.
Russia's hazards vary by region; floods, wildfires and thawing permafrost occur, but many areas have moderate risk with readiness.
Spring in Russia often swings 5-15°C; plan for layers as days warm and mornings chilly.
Russia's summers (e.g., Moscow) are 20–26°C with heatwaves to ~32°C; nights stay cool, so parks and outdoor time stay comfortable without heavy AC.
Autumn in Russia varies; many regions see mild days but early frosts and chilly evenings. Plan for layered clothing and occasional wind.
In Russia (RU), winters are often punishing with subzero temps and occasional -15°C spells, limiting outdoor family time.
Beaches in Russia are distant (Black Sea) and access from central cities is limited; not ideal for frequent family beach days.
Black Sea water off Russia stays around 22-26°C in peak summer; shoulder seasons may need light wetsuits for kids.
Russia's dramatic landscapes—mountains, lakes, tundra—offer striking scenery; many parks and reserves are within reach for weekly family trips.
Russia's regional minimums stay under 20,000 RUB (~$220), far short of a four-person family's needs. Extra income or subsidies are often required.
Russia (Moscow) senior software pay is ~2-3M RUB/yr; decent but below US hubs - remote work or dual incomes needed for comfort.
Russia has a sizable .NET market, but expat sponsorship is limited; expect local presence or bridging contracts. Some remote roles exist with multinationals.
Russia has pockets of Ruby roles in e-commerce, but talent relocated post-2022; expect remote work abroad rather than many local openings.
Russia does sponsor work visas through employers, but it's selective; expect slow processing and a premium for tech roles.
Russia's sanctions and war-time spending squeeze startups; funding and inflation challenge budgeting, though remote work may soften some pressures.
Remote work grows in RU IT hubs; Western tools face VPN/censorship hurdles; some office time may be needed.
Russia tech teams can crunch during releases; prefer remote/hybrid and explicit boundaries to protect family time.
Russia typically has a 40-hour week with overtime in the private sector; tech roles offer remote/hybrid options, but clear boundaries support family time.
Russia guarantees 28 days of annual leave plus public holidays, aiding family travel and work-life balance for the family.
Russia's 28-day annual leave is standard; many firms offer extra days and plan around holidays for longer breaks.
Russia: mid-sized cities outside Moscow/St. Petersburg offer a relaxed rhythm; pace suits a family seeking a slower-than-typical US metro lifestyle.
Russia schools typically 9:00–15:00; after-school care bridges gaps. With remote/hybrid work, wraparound options keep routine manageable.
Weekends go between Moscow-area parks and dachas. Local rallies or weather can shift plans, but there are plenty of kid-friendly activities.
Russia: family life is workable with effort; childcare access and English options vary, but cities offer public support for families.
In Russia, polyamorous families face social stigma and limited legal protections; custody and housing risks.
Russia (RU) parenting can be rigid due to state and social norms; autonomy may be limited and nonconformity scrutinized.
In Russia's Moscow and St. Petersburg, there are many parks and family zones; city centers are busy but manageable with planned outings.
Russia's major cities (Moscow, St. Petersburg) offer several good private/international schools, including bilingual options. Admissions and transfers require planning.
Pre-K exists in Russia, but state kindergartens have long waitlists; private care is costly and hours can be inflexible for working parents.
Russia offers maternity capital and subsidized preschool; bureaucracy is high, and costs still require top-ups for a two-child US family.
In Russia, visa holders have limited public childcare subsidies; access is rare and often subject to local quotas or private arrangements.
Russia's K-12 is public but varies by city; Moscow/St. Petersburg offer strong, bilingual options; smaller cities require careful school choice.
Russia: public schools are Russian-language; many expat families opt for international/private schools due to visas and language barriers.
International schools exist mainly in Moscow and St. Petersburg; tuition is high and admissions can be selective, but solid private options exist for expats.
Russia offers maternity capital and child allowances, but accessing benefits involves paperwork and delays; overall modest support for growing families.
Russia offers limited benefits to visa families. Emergency care is available, but regular support often requires residency or employer coverage.
In Russia, citizens have broad access to state-funded higher education, but many programs remain competitive and require entrance exams.
In Russia, international students typically face tuition fees with limited financial aid; English programs exist, but many courses require Russian.
In Kansas City, MO, gender roles are increasingly egalitarian. Trey and Sarah share parenting and careers with family-friendly options.
Russia (RU): gender-diverse identities face harassment and limited recognition; documentation and services remain challenging.
In Russia (RU), legal gender rights exist, but enforcement is uneven. Domestic violence protections are weak and pay gaps persist, affecting families.
In Russia, urban women have autonomy. Yet they face subtle appearance/parenting pressures in a country mixing progress with traditional norms.
Russia's traditional masculine norms remain strong; state messaging prizes toughness, with social pressure on nontraditional male roles.
Russia's rich literary and arts heritage offers engaging museum and theater moments. Moscow and St. Petersburg invite intentional exploration for culture-loving families.
In Russia, English ubiquity is low; paperwork and schooling mainly in Russian; plan language study and translation support.
In Russia, state ideology leans nationalist and socially conservative, clashing with the family's progressive values.
In Russia (Moscow), Marxism is largely nostalgic and fringe; it has little policy impact, though debates linger in urban circles.
In Russia, secular laws exist, but Orthodox culture shapes daily life; atheists face subtle bias.
Russia (RU): sex education is largely abstinence-focused. LGBTQ content is restricted, with resources uneven between cities and rural areas.
In Russia, LGBTQ+ protections are weak and anti-propaganda laws curb queer visibility. Safety planning is prudent for public life.
In Russia (RU), expat networks exist in Moscow and Saint Petersburg; outsiders may be met with reserve, but community forms via work, schools, and clubs.
Russia (RU) context: hopeful but prudent self-view; proud of pluralism, wary of power. We seek resilient institutions and civil liberties in our new home.
In Russia, neighboring countries are viewed cautiously; conflicts with Ukraine shape tense cross-border ties and limit travel or exchange.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Nearby European states view RU with distrust after aggression; cross-border travel and trade face tighter controls.
Nightlife exists in select districts of Russia's cities; for a family with kids, plan sitters and safe transport; late options can be limited.
Urban Russia (Moscow/St. Petersburg) features modern, diverse men's wear; suburbs stay classic, supporting a family-friendly, professional look.
Russia's urban centers (e.g., Moscow) show diverse fashion—from European chic to practical modesty. In workplaces and schools, polished, professional looks are common.
Ice skating and soccer are widespread in Russia, with many clubs and rinks. Gaming and board-game meetups are growing in major cities.
Boardgaming exists in Russia's big cities with clubs and cafes; sanctions limit imports, so expect some coordination to find regular groups.
In Moscow, Russia, live music is available with diverse venues; family-friendly events exist but often late - plan safe transport.
Russia's major cities (Moscow, St. Petersburg) host meetups, but many organizers have emigrated. Be prepared for proactive outreach to connect locally.
Nature access in Russia exists near major cities. Weekend car trips open forests and parks for family outings.
In Russia (RU), presidential power dominates; elections are managed and opposition limited; civil liberties and media plurality are restricted.
Russia's Orthodox Church wields notable sway in social policy; church-state ties shape education and family laws, reducing pluralism for LGBTQ+ rights.
Russia: labor laws exist but enforcement is spotty; unions weak and migrants face higher exploitation risk.
Russia's state ideology is authoritarian, suppressing dissent; this clashes with your progressive, rights-focused family values in RU.
Russia exhibits advanced backsliding: media and NGO crackdowns, limited civil liberties; risks to family safety and democratic norms.
In Russia, capitalism often leans toward elites and state-linked firms. This limits startup access and independent entrepreneurship.
In Russia, recurring crises and mobilization create daily uncertainty; war and sanctions affect planning.
Russia’s media leans state-aligned; independent outlets struggle for reach, making propaganda a noticeable feature in daily reporting.
In Russia, state-driven narratives dominate public messaging; independent outlets are limited, complicating neutral, pluralistic info for a progressive family.
In Russia, social safety nets are piecemeal and often politicized. Healthcare and childcare exist but are underfunded, limiting family-friendly support.
In Russia, government credibility is limited; state media dominates. Skepticism guides decisions for a progressive, family-focused profile.
In Russia, corruption is systemic across government levels. Bribes and opaque rules shape daily life and public services.
In Russia, system-wide corruption touches courts and utilities, risking reliable services and civil liberties for our family.
In Russia's major cities, family flats are pricey with tight stock; expect competition and deposits; consider smaller cities for space and value.
Russia (RU) safety varies; crime is moderate but policing can be arbitrary and war instability adds stress; plan security and avoid risky areas.
Russia has universal coverage, but regional underfunding and staff shortages cause delays. Urban centers fare better, private clinics fill gaps.
In Russia, visa families mainly rely on private clinics; public care for non-citizens is limited, and private insurance is typically needed.
Russia has public kindergartens but waitlists are common in big cities. Families rely on paid care and informal support.
Russia provides maternity capital and some childcare subsidies for two-child families, but regional rules and paperwork limit relief; costs remain partly private.
In Russia, public schools vary: solid STEM in cities, but civics follow state narratives; bilingual options are limited for progressive families.
Moscow/St. Petersburg have strong metro networks; however regional transit is patchier, so expect gaps if you venture beyond the cores.
Russia's economy remains state-dominated with sanctions curbing competition and Western access. Entrepreneurship faces higher barriers.
Russia's 13% flat tax is simple, but currency controls and foreign-asset reporting complicate expat finances.
Russia has a flat 13% personal income tax for residents (15% for non-residents). Overall taxes run ~13–15% with straightforward filing.
Banking in Russia relies on domestic cards (MIR) and QR payments; international transfers and foreign cards face strict limits, especially for non-residents.
Russia generally offers affordable groceries and transit; Moscow rents can be high, but many cities are affordable, leaving room for savings with remote work.
Russia's pension system faces funding gaps amid reform. For a family with young kids, retirement security depends on steady work.
Russia allows visa holders to contribute to public pensions. Access often depends on residency length and status, relevant for your long-term plans.
US citizens face opaque, changing visa routes to Russia; only select categories may open, with long processing and strict invites.
Russia (RU): US migrants face scrutiny amid tense relations; reception is cautious, with slow community integration for a family.
Residency in Russia exists but relies on work or family ties; for US first-time applicants, long-term status and renewals are often uncertain.
In Russia, naturalization typically requires ~5 years of residence, Russian language, and vetting; dual citizenship is allowed but the process is bureaucratic.
Russia allows spouses and minor children to accompany visa holders. With two parents and two kids, they can join via family visas.
In Russia, first-time US visa/permit processes can take up to a year. Plan for legal and translation fees.
Russia requires timely registration (propiska) and visa compliance; delays can trigger fines. As first-time US visa applicants, expect bureaucratic steps and checks.
Russia permits US–Russian dual citizenship; you must notify authorities and may face obligations.
Russia's visa process is tight; data monitoring and Western platform limits affect work; ongoing war risk adds uncertainty for families.
Russia's game dev scene is concentrated in Moscow/SPb; steady openings exist in studios and remote work, but publishing/funding are affected by sanctions.
In Russia, studios hire slowly due to sanctions; many rely on remote/global talent, which aligns with Trey's remote/game dev goals.
In Russia, established studios typically pay about 20% below top global hubs; negotiate remote roles or perk-rich packages, especially around Moscow.
In Russia, English is present in multinational studios; many teams are bilingual, though Russian dominates local docs.
Russia: established studios largely require on-site work; remote/hybrid cases are evaluated individually, fitting the family's preference for flexible roles.
Russia has several notable studios (Gaijin, Saber, Playrix, 1C) with ongoing releases. Moscow and St. Petersburg host active dev networks.
Moscow and St. Petersburg host active game dev scenes (DevGamm, local meetups) plus robust online hubs; newcomers can engage with some effort.
In Russia (RU), access to capital and global distribution is constrained by sanctions; local talent exists, but funding is scarce.
Russia startup hiring is slow due to sanctions; many roles rely on remote talent or relocation, complicating founder plans.
Russia startup pay lags global peers; cash + equity balance common to stay competitive in Moscow/Russia, with wide equity terms.
In Russia, startups use English for investors and platforms; local Russian fluency supports hiring, compliance, and outreach.
In Russia, startup teams are still mostly on-site (Moscow/major cities). Remote work is rarely supported; hybrid options are limited and require negotiation.
In Russia, urban infrastructure is solid with good utilities and broadband. However, regional gaps and sanctions can cause outages.
In Russia (RU), long cold winters bring notable seasonal swings; monitor forecasts for heating needs and travel disruptions.
Russia's seasonal light varies; in Moscow daylight ranges about 8–17 hours. Plan outdoor time and light routines to stay energized.
Russia (Moscow): long winters; only brief shoulder weeks feel good; spring/fall windows are short, so outdoor plans are flexible.
Russia: a 4-person family with ~$30k cash can cover basics with budgeting; public healthcare helps, but housing in big cities is tight.
Russia offers affordable housing and solid public services for a middle-income family, but language barriers and cold climate may squeeze budgets.
In Russia, premium services cluster in Moscow and Saint Petersburg. Elite schooling and wealth management are concentrated there, requiring expat planning.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: In Russia, 2k sq ft rentals are rare; expect smaller spaces or relocating to a larger metro like Moscow or St. Petersburg for space.
Russia (RU): formal community living is scarce; only a few co-housing options exist in Moscow or St. Petersburg; otherwise rely on informal networks.
Russia: friendliness varies by district; expat networks exist in Moscow/St. Petersburg. Outreach and international neighborhoods aid integration.
Russia can be unfriendly to immigrants; foreign families may face social scrutiny, xenophobia, and bureaucratic hurdles in cities like Moscow.
Russia: a US family in Moscow may face mixed reactions. Quick language learning and active community engagement help avoid aloofness.
In Russia, surface interactions are brisk but respectful; warmth can vary by context, especially in urban centers like Moscow.
In Russia, deep bonds are hard to form. Expats in Moscow often feel on the periphery due to wary social circles.
RU: in crowded cities, proximity can be close. Be ready to politely set boundaries around kids in transit and public spaces.
In Russia (RU), privacy matters; we keep personal matters private to avoid gossip or judgment among local communities.
Russia (RU): In urban Russia, daily grooming is common; this can pressure a low-maintenance family seeking simplicity.
In Russia, body-image pressure and dieting talk surface in schools and media. This shapes kids' social circles and self-image.
Kansas City, Missouri, USA favors practical, casual-to-smart-casual attire; fashion norms are relaxed for tech families and remote work.
Russia's climate includes LGBTQ+ hostility and weak consent norms; harassment risk is real—proactive safety plans for the family are essential.
In Russia (RU), traditional gender norms persist. Nontraditional flirting may face pushback, though Moscow/St. Petersburg show pockets of openness.
In Russia (RU), non-monogamy faces hostile norms. Disclosure is risky for families seeking stability and civil protections.
In Kansas City, USA, a sex-positive, progressive milieu; casual sex is accepted and nonmonogamy is respected with little stigma.
Russia (RU): polyamory faces legal limits and social hostility; privacy crucial to avoid discrimination.
In Russia's urban life, crowded transit is common; we can politely seek space, but close contact happens in public settings.
Russia's gun laws require licensing and safe storage; ownership exists but is tightly regulated, keeping daily firearm exposure relatively controlled.
In Russia (RU), even minor drug infractions risk arrest and possible deportation for non-citizens; enforcement is strict.
Enforcement in Russia can be aggressive and uneven; harsh penalties and limited rights protections threaten family stability.
In Russia, mass violence is an ongoing concern. Stay alert at large events in Moscow or St. Petersburg, and follow local guidance.
Russia's prison system shows ongoing abuses and slow reforms. Detainee rights and oversight gaps raise risk for migrants.
Walkability in Russia varies by city; pick walkable districts with parks, since sidewalks can be uneven and traffic can be busy.
In Russia (RU), healthcare is public but wellness programs vary; in cities like Moscow you can find parks and gyms, but you'll need to seek like-minded groups.
In Russia's cities, fresh markets exist but processed foods are common; plan to shop at markets to balance meals.
In Russia, fresh markets exist in big cities, but international options are limited to a few neighborhoods; you may need trips for specialty ingredients.
Depression care in Russia is variable; urban clinics exist, but long waits and patchy coverage hinder families like ours in RU.
In Russia, obesity is moderately common; youth rates are rising in urban areas. Encourage daily activity and healthy eating for the family.
Russia shows higher cancer incidence due to lifestyle and environmental factors; emphasize accessible screening and healthier environments in urban centers.
Russia's job market is energy/state-driven; downturns hit segments. Stay flexible, build savings, and keep remote work options for resilience.
Russia's game-dev scene is centered in Moscow and St. Petersburg, with dozens of studios and an active indie sector. Funding varies by region.
Russia's Moscow/St. Petersburg hubs host Wargaming (AAA) along with Gaijin and 1C; multiple anchors offer steady jobs and game-dev training.
Russia has a workable game-dev vendor scene in Moscow and St. Petersburg for art/QA and engineering. However sanctions and cross-border payments can limit scale.
In Russia, CS programs exist, but game-focused pipelines are uneven. Moscow and other cities rely on bootcamps/private schools for game roles.
In Russia, CE exists via universities and occasional meetups; English options are limited; plan for quarterly events and online courses.
Russia hosts regular monthly game-dev meetups in Moscow and St. Petersburg. Occasional game jams also occur, keeping the community connected.
Russia's Unity and Unreal communities are active in Moscow and St. Petersburg, with cross-training and shared resources across studios.
Russia's real-time game dev scene is active (Moscow/SPB) with strong broadband; some pre-rendered work exists, though funding can be variable.
Russia's software/dev market is in steady demand; talent is plentiful, but senior Unity/.NET skills face competition; remote work helps.
Russia has a growing game-dev scene (Moscow/SPb), but sanctions and conflict risk raise churn; expect moderate retention and project-based staffing.
Russia's D&I landscape is constrained with limited LGBTQ+ protections and sparse, opaque metrics. Inclusion efforts are in early stages, with progress uneven.
Russia offers few game-specific tax credits; only general IT/culture subsidies exist, with limited payouts and opaque eligibility.
Russia's policy climate can shift abruptly; plan for grants, tax rules, and visas; contingency advised; monitor Moscow's regulatory signals.
Russia's startup scene in Moscow is growing with regular meetups. Foreign founders can access hubs like Skolkovo/IIDF, though visa hurdles exist.
In Russia (Moscow), early-stage game funding exists via mixed funds and public grants (RVC, Skolkovo). Access is competitive and local capital is limited.

Russia has a decent IT freelancer pool in Moscow and SPB, but visa/tax complexity and sanctions slow onboarding.
Russia (Moscow/St. Petersburg) offers solid coworking with game-dev communities; mocap gear and dedicated labs are limited.
Russia (RU): Only a few game/IP specialists operate; startups rely on referrals. For global licenses, expect cross-border counsel beyond local firms.
Russia (RU) has limited local publisher presence. Founders would rely on international events and remote outreach.
Russia has local playtest groups and events, but scalable, frequent playtesting is limited; expect ad hoc panels and longer lead times.
In Russia (RU), startup visas are limited; as a US family you’d likely need corporate sponsorship or relocate for work permits.
Russia offers affordable dev talent, but Moscow rents and inflation raise costs. Leverage IT incentives to extend runway.

Russia (Moscow/St. Petersburg) has several animation/VFX programs, but 3D character pipelines are uneven. Studios bridge gaps with targeted upskilling.
Russia has sporadic 3D character art workshops and local courses (Moscow/SPb); most upskilling is online or remote.
Russia RU: 3D character artist roles typically take 4–5 months with several cycles; remote/global talent helps offset local pipeline gaps.
Russia's 3D character artist compensation trails top hubs by ~25-30%. Cost of living is lower and benefits vary by employer.
RU studios in Moscow/St. Petersburg use English widely; many 3D artists are bilingual. Some teams still rely on Russian; plan for language screening.
Russia (Moscow) supports remote 3D character work, but many studios favor hybrid setups; US time zones demand async workflows; fully remote is by exception.
Solid pool of 3D animators in Moscow and St. Petersburg; a few studios dominate, making senior hires competitive.
Russia has a few dedicated animation programs in Moscow and St. Petersburg; grads often require on-the-job upskilling for local studios.
Moscow and St. Petersburg offer sporadic 3D animation training; expect occasional workshops or remote courses rather than steady local programs.

In Russia (Moscow/St. Petersburg), 3D animator roles exist with remote/hybrid options, but access varies by project.
Russia hosts a solid 2D environmental art pool, led by Moscow and St. Petersburg studios; competition for senior roles is noticeable.
Russia has a few reputable art/CG programs in Moscow and St. Petersburg. 2D environment art graduates feed into regional studios with solid portfolios.
Russia offers sporadic in-person 2D environmental art courses (Moscow/St. Petersburg) plus online options; most learning is self-directed.
In Russia (Moscow), 2D environmental artist roles typically run 4–5 months. Visa/relocation steps can extend timelines for international hires.
Russia (Moscow): 2D Environmental Artist pay ~25–30% below top markets. Lower living costs ease the gap, but packages still lag Western hubs.
Russia (Moscow/SPB): English-capable 2D environmental artists exist mainly in multinationals. Indie studios lean Russian, so plan for English screening.
In Russia, remote/hybrid 2D environmental artist roles are common. Fully remote arrangements usually require negotiation and clear milestones.

Russia's VFX real-time pipeline: VGIK and a couple reputable programs consistently place grads into Moscow studios.
Russia offers occasional VFX real-time training; learning mainly online or via visiting experts; Moscow/SPb host intermittent workshops.

In Russia (Moscow), VFX Real-Time pay trails top markets by 25-30%; lower living costs help offset the gap.
Russia (RU): English is common in multinational VFX studios, but many local shops use Russian; bilingual ability helps in Moscow and St. Petersburg.

Remote options for real-time VFX in Russia exist case-by-case with limited process maturity. Hybrids or onsite work are common; prioritize senior or trusted contractors to fit a family-friendly schedule.
Russia's community manager pool is moderate, concentrated in Moscow and St. Petersburg; startups may need relocation or remote options for senior roles.
Russia has solid IT/marketing programs in Moscow and St. Petersburg; dedicated community manager curricula are scarce, so on-the-job upskilling is common.
Russia has limited local Community Manager education; rely on online courses and occasional Moscow/SPB workshops; most learning is self-directed.
Russia: community manager roles typically require 4–5 months; local pipelines are modest—remote/relocation or English-friendly options help.
Russia (Moscow): CM compensation trails top markets by about 25-30%; lifestyle and remote options help offset the pay.
Russia CM market: English is common in IT, but client-facing roles prefer bilingual (EN/RU); fits family goal of English ubiquity and learning Russian.
In Russia, studios often support hybrid/remote Community Managers with async workflows. Expect occasional on-site sessions in major cities.
Russia's game product marketing managers represent a moderate pool (Moscow/St. Petersburg). Senior roles may require relocation or remote options.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Education Pipeline Strength
values.alignmentText: Russia lacks dedicated Game PMM curricula; mainly short certificates exist and graduates need mentoring; stronger options cluster around Moscow.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Continuing Education Availability
values.alignmentText: Russia has occasional PMM (games) training; Moscow & St. Petersburg host events and online courses, but local programs are limited; remote options prevail.
Russia's PMM (Games) hiring in Moscow/St. Petersburg typically takes 2–3 months with a solid local talent pool. Expect some Russian-language requirements.
Russia PMM (Games) pay trails top markets by ~25–30%; Moscow roles offer lower cost of living and remote options.
Russia: PMM (Games) roles tend to be Russian-speaking; English common in multinationals (Moscow/SPB), with some Russian onboarding.
Russia (RU): remote game PM roles exist case-by-case; limited maturity but flexible for remote/hybrid to suit a family-friendly pace.
